bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In these Supreme Court Family Rules, unless the context otherwise requires:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: accessible address means an address that describes a unique and identifiable location in British Columbia that is accessible to the public during normal business hours for the delivery of documents;
application means an application made before trial to obtain a court order or an application, whenever made, to change a final order;
arbitration award means an award, within the meaning of the Arbitration Act, made in respect of a family law dispute;
business day means a day on which the court registries are open for business;
Chief Justice means the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of British Columbia;
claimant means a person who has filed a notice of family claim under Rule 4-1;
court means the Supreme Court of British Columbia and, if an associate judge has jurisdiction, includes an associate judge of the Supreme Court;
Divorce Act means the Divorce Act (Canada);

document has an extended meaning and includes a photograph, film, recording of sound, any record of a permanent or semi-permanent character and any information recorded or stored by means of any device;

family justice counsellor means a person appointed as a family court counsellor under section 3 of the Family Relations Act or a person appointed as a family justice counsellor under section 10 of the Family Law Act;
family law case means a proceeding in which one or more of the following orders is sought:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order under the Divorce Act;
an order under the Family Law Act;
a FHRMIRA order;
an order for annulment of marriage;
an order,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: based on unjust enrichment or other trust claims, for an interest in property, or
based on unjust enrichment, for compensation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the claim for the interest or compensation arises out of a marriage-like relationship;
an order for adoption,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: and includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a proceeding that, under Rule 3-1 (4.1), was started by the filing of a requisition and agreement under Rule 2-1 (1),
a proceeding that, under Rule 3-1 (4.4), was started by the filing of a requisition under Rule 20-6 (3), and
a proceeding that, under Rule 3-1 (4.5), was started by the filing of a requisition and arbitration award under Rule 2-1.2 (2);

bcl:text.in:em: [Orders available under a family law case include orders concerning guardianship, parenting arrangements or contact with a child, orders for support for a child or spouse, protection orders, orders dealing with property and divorce orders.]

bcl:definition.bcl:text: FHRMIRA order means an order made under the Family Homes on Reserves and Matrimonial Interests or Rights Act (Canada) or under a First Nation's law made under that Act;
file means file in the registry;
final order means an order finally resolving a claim in a family law case even though the order may be subject to change;
FMEP Director means the Director of Maintenance Enforcement under the Family Maintenance Enforcement Act;
former Supreme Court Rules means the Supreme Court Rules, B.C. Reg. 221/90;
joint family law case means a family law case referred to in Rule 2-2 (1);
notice of application means the document described in Rule 10-6 (3);
party means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a claimant,
a respondent,
a respondent by way of counterclaim,
a petitioner,
a petition respondent, and
if a support order is filed with him or her, the FMEP Director in relation to the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: any matter arising under section 9, 14 (1) or (2), 16 (3) or (4), 18 (2), 19, 20, 21, 22 (1), 23 (1), 26 (10), 29, 30, 30.1, 31, 39 (1) or 46 (1) of the Family Maintenance Enforcement Act;
an application to change, suspend or terminate a support order that is in arrears, other than a support order under the Divorce Act;

an application to change, suspend or terminate a support order made under the Divorce Act if the order has been assigned to a minister designated by the Lieutenant Governor in Council under the Divorce Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: petition proceeding means a family law case started by a petition;
petition respondent means a person who has filed a response to petition under Rule 17-1 (4);
petitioner means a person who has filed a petition under Rule 17-1;
pleading means a notice of family claim, a response to family claim, a counterclaim and a response to counterclaim;

regional manager in relation to a registry, means the regional manager of the Family Justice Services Division (Justice Services Branch), Ministry of Attorney General, who is responsible for the region in which the registry is located;
registrar includes a district registrar and a deputy district registrar;
registry, in relation to a family law case, means the office of the court in which the family law case is being conducted;
relief includes remedy;
respondent means a person who has filed a response to family claim under Rule 4-3;
respondent by way of counterclaim means a person who has filed a response to counterclaim under Rule 4-4 (5);
support includes maintenance;
undefended family law case means a family law case in which one of the following is true:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the family law case is a joint family law case and no party has filed a notice of withdrawal;
no response to family claim has been filed;
a response to family claim was filed but has been withdrawn or struck out;
a response to family claim and a counterclaim have been filed but the notice of family claim and any response to counterclaim have been

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: withdrawn, or
struck out, discontinued or dismissed;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all claims other than a claim for divorce, if any, have been settled, the parties have filed a statement to that effect signed by the parties or their lawyers and the claim for divorce, if any, is not contested.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Interpretation Act and Supreme Court Act
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless a contrary intention appears, the Interpretation Act and the interpretation section of the Supreme Court Act apply to these Supreme Court Family Rules.
The titles and headings of these Supreme Court Family Rules are for convenience only and are not intended as a guide to interpretation.

Italicized words in square brackets are not part of these Supreme Court Family Rules, are included editorially for convenience of reference only and are not to be used in interpreting the rules or any provision to which the words refer.
These Supreme Court Family Rules may be cited as the "Supreme Court Family Rules" and are included within any citation to the "Rules of Court" or the "Supreme Court Rules".

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Rules apply to all family law cases
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: These Supreme Court Family Rules apply to all family law cases.
On application, and if all parties to a family law case agree, the court may order that any provision of these Supreme Court Family Rules does not apply to the family law case.
The object of these Supreme Court Family Rules is to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: help parties resolve the legal issues in a family law case fairly and in a way that will

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: take into account the impact that the conduct of the family law case may have on a child, and
minimize conflict and promote cooperation between the parties, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: secure the just, speedy and inexpensive determination of every family law case on its merits.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Securing the just, speedy and inexpensive determination of a family law case on its merits includes, so far as is practicable, conducting the family law case in ways that are proportionate to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the interests of any child affected,
the importance of the issues in dispute, and
the complexity of the family law case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A copy of a written agreement referred to in section 15, 44 (3), 58 (3), 148 (2) or 163 (3) of the Family Law Act may be filed.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing agreements under the Family Law Act
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To file an agreement under subrule (1), a copy of the agreement must be attached to a requisition in Form F17.1 and the requisition must be filed.

Without limiting any other power the court may have to enforce an agreement filed under this rule, the court may make an order for that purpose on an application and, for that purpose, Part 10 of these Supreme Court Family Rules applies.
Subject to subrule (2), a determination of a parenting coordinator referred to in section 18 of the Family Law Act may be filed in a family law case.

If the parenting coordinator who makes a determination was engaged under an agreement referred to in section 15 (1) of the Family Law Act, the determination must not be filed until that agreement has been filed under Rule 2-1.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing determinations under the Family Law Act
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To file a determination under subrule (1), a copy of the determination must be attached to a requisition in Form F17.2 and the requisition must be filed.
An arbitration award may be filed in a registry.
To file an arbitration award under subrule (1), a certified copy of the arbitration award must be attached to a requisition in Form F17.3 and the requisition must be filed.
A family law case may be started jointly by the persons involved if all relief, except any claim for divorce, is by consent.

bcl:lefttext.in:em: [See Rule 10-10 for the process to be followed for obtaining judgment in a joint family law case.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Notice of family claim in joint family law case
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In a joint family law case, the notice of family claim

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: must be in Form F1, and
need not be served.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Withdrawal from joint family law case
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person may withdraw from a joint family law case by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: filing a notice of withdrawal in Form F2, and
serving a copy of the filed notice of withdrawal by personal service in accordance with Rule 6-3 (2).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person who withdraws from a joint family law case wishes to oppose a claim made in the joint notice of family claim or wishes to claim other relief, that person must, at the time of filing the notice of withdrawal, file a response to family claim or counterclaim or both.
If a notice of withdrawal is filed under subrule (3), these Supreme Court Family Rules apply to the family law case as if it were not a joint family law case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application under Part 2 of the Civil Marriage Act (Canada)
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In this Rule,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: court order, in respect of a marriage to which Part 2 of the Civil Marriage Act (Canada) applies, means a certified copy of an order from a court in the jurisdiction where one of the spouses resides declaring that the other spouse

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is incapable of making decisions about his or her civil status because of a mental disability,
is unreasonably withholding consent, or
cannot be found;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: supporting affidavit means an affidavit respecting the grounds for divorce as set out in section 7 (1) of the Civil Marriage Act (Canada).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A divorce under Part 2 of the Civil Marriage Act (Canada) may be sought by filing all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an application in Form F1.1;
the marriage certificate;
the applicable of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a supporting affidavit sworn by both spouses;
supporting affidavits sworn by each spouse;
a supporting affidavit sworn by the applicant spouse and a court order respecting the other spouse.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A certificate of divorce referred to in section 9 of the Civil Marriage Act (Canada) must be in Form F1.2 and may be signed and issued by the registrar.

bcl:part.bcl:text: How to Start and Defend a Family Law Case

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Choosing the Correct Form of Proceeding

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Commencing family law cases by notice of family claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Except for those special situations referred to in subrules (2.1) to (2.4), (4.1), (4.4) and (4.5) of this rule, every family law case must be started by filing a notice of family claim under Rule 4-1.
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 133/2012, s. 3 (b).]
A joint family law case must be started in accordance with Rule 2-2.
The following orders must be sought in a family law case started in accordance with subrule (3) of this rule:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order for adoption;
an order for return of a child under the Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction signed at The Hague on October 25, 1980;
an order granting a person, other than a spouse,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: leave under section 16.1 (3) of the Divorce Act to make an application for a parenting order or interim parenting order in respect of a child, or
leave under section 16.5 (3) of the Divorce Act to make an application for a contact order or interim contact order that provides for contact between the person and a child;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order granting a person, other than a former spouse, to whom a parenting order does not relate leave under section 17 (2) of the Divorce Act to make an application for an order varying, rescinding or suspending the parenting order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An order for a declaration of parentage must be sought in a family law case

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: started by filing a notice of family claim under Rule 4-1, or
in accordance with subrule (4) of this rule.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When petitions or applications must be used
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The following orders must be sought in accordance with subrule (4) of this rule:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order under section 35 or 36 of the Family Law Act to recognize a Canadian extraprovincial declaratory order or a non-Canadian extraprovincial declaratory order respectively;
directions sought by a guardian of a child under section 49 of the Family Law Act;
an order under section 75 of the Family Law Act to recognize an extra provincial order;
an order under section 231 (4) of the Family Law Act to apprehend a child;
an order under the Divorce Act to vary, rescind or suspend a support order, parenting order or contact order of another court;
an order under section 183 of the Family Law Act;
an order under section 28 of the Child, Family and Community Service Act;

an order under section 10 of the Family Orders and Agreements Enforcement Assistance Act (Canada) authorizing an official of the court to make an application under section 12 of that Act for the release of information.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To obtain any of the orders referred to in subrule (2.2), a person must start a family law case by petition under Rule 17-1 and seek the order within that family law case.
To obtain any of the orders referred to in subrule (2.3) (b) or (2.4) of this rule, a person must apply for the order as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if there is an existing family law case within which, under these Supreme Court Family Rules, it is appropriate to seek that order, the application for that order must be made in that family law case;

if there is no existing family law case within which it is appropriate to seek that order, a person wishing to obtain that order must start a family law case by petition under Rule 17-1 and seek the order within that family law case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing agreements under the Family Law Act
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person files under Rule 2-1 (2) a requisition to which an agreement is attached and there is no existing family law case within which it is appropriate to file the requisition, the filing of the requisition under that rule starts a family law case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Style of proceedings if filing of agreement starts family law case
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the filing of a requisition starts a family law case under subrule (4.1) of this rule, the style of proceeding in the family law case must name the person filing the requisition as "Claimant" and the other parties to the agreement as "Respondents".

Without limiting Rule 2-1.1 (2), if a person wishes to file a determination of a parenting coordinator under Rule 2-1.1 and there is no existing family law case within which it is appropriate to file the determination, the person must first start a family law case under subrule (4.1) of this rule and file the determination within that family law case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing a requisition to appoint a litigation representative
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person files a requisition under Rule 20-6 (3) and there is no existing family law case within which it is appropriate to file the requisition, the filing of that requisition under that rule starts a family law case, the style of proceeding of which must be "In the Matter of the Estate of" followed by the name of the deceased.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing arbitration awards under the Family Law Act
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a person files under Rule 2-1.2 (1) a requisition to which an arbitration award is attached and there is no existing family law case within which it is appropriate to file the requisition, the filing of the requisition under that rule starts a family law case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Style of proceedings if filing of arbitration award starts family law case
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the filing of a requisition starts a family law case under subrule (4.5) of this rule, the style of proceeding in the family law case must name the person filing the requisition as "Claimant" and the other parties to the arbitration as "Respondents".

A claim that, on its own, would not be the subject matter of a family law case may be brought in a family law case, and a person by or against whom any such claim is made may be added as a party in that family law case, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: relief referred to in paragraph (a), (b), (c), (d) or (e) of the definition of "family law case" in Rule 1-1 is being sought in the family law case, and
the claim is related to or connected with any of that relief.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Family Law Cases Started by Filing a Notice of Family Claim

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To start a family law case other than a family law case referred to in Rule 3-1 (2.1), (2.2), (2.3) (b), (2.4) or (4.1), a person must file a notice of family claim in Form F3.

bcl:text.in:em: [A joint family law case is to be brought under Rule 2-2.]
[An application to change, suspend or terminate an existing order is to be brought under Part 10.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: After filing a notice of family claim, the claimant must serve a copy of the filed notice of family claim on each of the persons named as a respondent in the notice of family claim

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: by personal service in accordance with Rule 6-3 (2), or
if the court makes an order under Rule 6-4 (1) allowing service by an alternative method, by that alternative method.

bcl:lefttext.in:em: [Rule 4-2 limits the time for service.]
[Part 6 provides instructions about service.]

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Serving and Renewing the Notice of Family Claim

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Renewal of original notice of family claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An original notice of family claim does not remain in force for more than 12 months, but if a respondent named in a notice of family claim has not been served, the court, on the application of the claimant made before or after the expiration of the 12 months, may order that the original notice of family claim be renewed for a period of not more than 12 months.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Further renewal of notice of family claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a renewed notice of family claim has not been served on a respondent named in the notice of family claim, the court, on the application of the claimant made during the currency of the renewed notice of family claim, may order the renewal of the notice of family claim for a further period of not more than 12 months.
Unless the court otherwise orders, a renewal period ordered under subrule (1) or (2) begins on the date of the order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: After renewal of notice of family claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, a copy of each order granting renewal of a notice of family claim must be served with the renewed notice of family claim, and the renewed notice of family claim remains in force and is available to prevent the operation of any statutory limitation and for all other purposes.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Responding to a Notice of Family Claim

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Filing a response to family claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To respond to a notice of family claim, a person must, within 30 days after being served,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a response to family claim in Form F4, and
serve a copy of the filed response to family claim on the claimant and on the other persons named in the notice of family claim as respondents.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: No notice of hearing if no response to family claim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person served with a notice of family claim under Rule 4-1 (2) who does not file a response to family claim in accordance with subrule (1) of this rule is not entitled to receive notice of any part of the family law case including, without limitation, any court appearance, hearing, conference or trial.
In addition to filing a response to family claim under Rule 4-3, a respondent may bring one or more of the following against the claimant:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a claim under the Divorce Act;
a claim under the Family Law Act;
a claim for a FHRMIRA order;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 133/2012, s. 6 (a).]
a claim for annulment of marriage;
a claim,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: based on unjust enrichment or other trust claims, for an interest in property, or
based on unjust enrichment, for compensation

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the claim for the interest or compensation arises out of a marriage-like relationship;
a claim that, on its own, would not be the subject matter of a family law case if the claim is related to or connected with any of the relief sought in the family law case.

bcl:text.in:em: [Orders that may be sought under subrule (1) include orders concerning guardianship, parenting arrangements or contact with a child, orders for support for a child or spouse, protection orders, orders dealing with property and divorce orders.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To seek an order referred to in subrule (1) of this rule, a party named as a respondent must file a counterclaim in Form F5 within 30 days after being served with the notice of family claim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Counterclaim may include claims against persons other than the claimant
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If one or more of the claims made in a counterclaim brought by a respondent against the claimant also relate to another person, the respondent may name that other person as a respondent to the counterclaim.
A respondent who files a counterclaim must,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: within 30 days after being served with the notice of family claim, serve a copy of the filed counterclaim by ordinary service on all parties, and

within 60 days after being served with the notice of family claim, serve a copy of the filed counterclaim and a copy of the filed notice of family claim by personal service in accordance with Rule 6-3 (2) on any person who is not yet a party to the family law case but against whom a claim is made in the counterclaim.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Parties against whom relief is sought must respond
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To respond to a counterclaim, the claimant and any other person named as a respondent to the counterclaim must, within 30 days after being served,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a response to counterclaim in Form F6, and
serve a copy of the filed response to counterclaim on all parties.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: No notice of hearing if no response to counterclaim
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A person referred to in subrule (4) (b) who does not file a response to counterclaim in accordance with subrule (5) is not entitled to receive notice of any part of the family law case including, without limitation, any court appearance, hearing, conference or trial.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If family law case stayed or discontinued
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A respondent's counterclaim in a family law case may proceed even though the claimant's claim in the family law case has been stayed, discontinued or dismissed.

If, on the application of a party against whom a counterclaim is made, it appears that the subject matter of the counterclaim ought to be dealt with separately, the court may order that the counterclaim be struck out or tried separately or may make any other order the court considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Family Rules.

If a set-off or counterclaim establishes a defence to the claimant's claim, the court may grant judgment in favour of the respondent for any balance in the respondent's favour or for other relief as the court considers appropriate.

bcl:rule.bcl:text: Other Rules about Notice of Family Claim Cases

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If it is alleged in a notice of family claim or counterclaim that a spouse has committed adultery with another person,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that other person must not be identified in the notice of family claim or counterclaim unless that other person is named as a party to the family law case,
that other person must not be named as a party to the family law case unless relief, other than or in addition to costs, is claimed against the person, and

the identity of that other person may be demanded by the party alleging adultery, but any information provided in response to that demand must not be filed before the trial or application for final order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The first person to file in a family law case a document in which a claim for divorce or nullity is made must file with that document a certificate of the marriage or of registration of the marriage unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the filed document

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: sets out the reasons why the certificate is not being filed with the document and states that the certificate will be filed before the family law case is set down for trial or before an application is made for an order of divorce or nullity, or
sets out the reasons why it is impossible to file a certificate, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the registrar is satisfied with the reasons given for the failure or inability to file such a certificate.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In a family law case in which a divorce is claimed, a party who has filed a pleading may withdraw that document or any part of it by filing and serving a notice of withdrawal in Form F7.
A party must not, in a pleading, make an allegation of fact or raise a new ground or claim inconsistent with the party's previous pleading.
Subrule (1) does not affect the right of a party to make allegations in the alternative or to amend or apply for leave to amend a pleading.
The court may order a party to serve further and better particulars of a matter stated in a pleading.
Before applying to the court for particulars, a party must demand them in writing from the other party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Demand for particulars not a stay of proceedings
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A demand for particulars does not operate as a stay of proceedings or give an extension of time, but a party may apply for an extension of time for serving a response to family claim or a response to counterclaim on the ground that the party cannot answer the notice of family claim or counterclaim respectively until particulars are provided.
In this rule:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: applicable income documents means, in respect of a person,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of every personal income tax return filed by the person for each of the 3 most recent taxation years,
a copy of every notice of income tax assessment or reassessment issued to the person for each of the 3 most recent taxation years,
if the person is receiving employment insurance benefits, a copy of the 3 most recent employment insurance benefit statements,
if the person is receiving workers' compensation benefits, a copy of the 3 most recent workers' compensation benefit statements,
if the person is receiving income assistance, current documentary evidence of the income assistance that is being received by that person,
if the person is an employee,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the most recent statement of earnings indicating the total earnings paid to the person in the year to date, including overtime, or

if that statement is not provided by the employer, a letter from the person's employer setting out the information referred to in sub-paragraph (i) and including the person's rate of annual salary or remuneration,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person is self employed, the following information for the 3 most recent taxation years:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the financial statements of the person's business or professional practice, other than a partnership;

a statement showing a breakdown of all salaries, wages, management fees or other payments or benefits paid to, or on behalf of, persons or corporations with whom the person does not deal at arm's length,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person is a partner in a partnership, confirmation of the person's income and draw from, and capital in, the partnership for each of its 3 most recent taxation years,
if the person controls a corporation, the following information for the corporation's 3 most recent taxation years:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the financial statements of the corporation and its subsidiaries;

a statement showing a breakdown of all salaries, wages, management fees or other payments or benefits paid to, or on behalf of, persons or corporations with whom the corporation and every related corporation does not deal at arm's length,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the person is a beneficiary under a trust, a copy of the trust settlement agreement and copies of the trust's 3 most recent financial statements, and
if the person owns or has an interest in real property, a copy of the most recent assessment notice issued from an assessment authority for each property;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: child support guidelines means,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in reference to a claim under the Family Law Act, the child support guidelines established under the Family Law Act, or
in reference to a claim under the Divorce Act, the child support guidelines established under the Divorce Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: income assistance includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: income assistance within the meaning of the Employment and Assistance Act, and
disability assistance within the meaning of the Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: party means a person named as a party to a family law case who is claiming, or against whom is claimed,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order for child support or an order changing, suspending or terminating an order for child support,
an order for spousal support or an order changing, suspending or terminating an order for spousal support,
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 133/2012, s. 7 (c), as am. by B.C. Reg. 67/2013, s. 1 (c).]
relief under Part 5 of the Family Law Act, or
a FHRMIRA order;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: stepparent means, in relation to a child,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a stepparent of the child within the meaning of section 146 of the Family Law Act, or
a person who stands in the place of a parent for the child within the meaning of the Divorce Act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule applies to a family law case as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if, in the family law case, a person is seeking to obtain or to change, suspend or terminate an order for child support, subrules (1), (3) to (8) and (11) to (32) apply;
if, in the family law case, a person is seeking to obtain, review or change, suspend or terminate an order for spousal support, subrules (1), (3), (9) and (11) to (32) apply;
if, in the family law case, a person is seeking to obtain or to change, suspend or terminate an order for relief under Part 5 of the Family Law Act, subrules (1), (3) and (10) to (32) apply;
if, in the family law case, a person is seeking to obtain, vary or revoke a FHRMIRA order, subrules (1), (3) and (10) to (32) apply;

if, in the family law case, a person is seeking to set aside or replace the whole or any part of that portion of an agreement that deals with child support, subrules (1), (3) to (8) and (11) to (32) apply;

if, in the family law case, a person is seeking to review, set aside or replace the whole or any part of that portion of an agreement that deals with spousal support, subrules (1), (3), (9) and (11) to (32) apply.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Each page of the applicable income documents that are to be used in court must be numbered sequentially.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Who must provide Part 1 of a Form F8 financial statement
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Each party who is required under the child support guidelines to provide income information must file the following documents and must serve them under subrule (11):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Part 1 of a Form F8 financial statement;
the party's applicable income documents;
any other documents that the party is required to file and serve under subrules (5) to (7).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Who must provide Parts 2 and 3 of a Form F8 financial statement
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In addition to any other documents a party is obliged to file and serve under this rule, the party must file Parts 2 and 3 of a Form F8 financial statement and must serve those documents under subrule (11), if one of the following is true:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the child support guidelines require the court to consider any or all of the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the financial ability of the parties;
the means of the parties;
the condition, means, needs and other circumstances of the parties or the child;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party who is to pay the child support is a stepparent of the child.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If special or extraordinary expenses are claimed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party who makes a claim for special or extraordinary expenses must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file Part 4 of a Form F8 financial statement, in addition to any other documents the party is obliged to file under this rule, and
serve that Part 4 under subrule (11).

bcl:lefttext.in:em: ["Special or extraordinary expenses" is defined in section 7 of the child support guidelines.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In addition to any other documents that a party is obliged to file and serve under this rule, if a claim for undue hardship is made,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party making the claim for undue hardship must file and serve, under subrule (11), Parts 1, 2, 3, 5 and 6 of a Form F8 financial statement along with that party's applicable income documents, and

unless the court otherwise orders, a party other than the party making the claim for undue hardship must file and serve, under subrule (11), Parts 1, 2, 3 and 6 of a Form F8 financial statement along with that party's applicable income documents.

bcl:lefttext.in:em: ["Undue hardship" is defined in section 10 of the child support guidelines.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Parties are deemed to have complied with the requirements of the child support guidelines respecting the provision of documents, and with the requirements of this rule, as it applies to child support, respecting the filing and service of documents, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the parties have agreed on the annual income of the party who is to pay the child support,
the parties have signed an agreement in Form F9, and
the agreement in Form F9 has been filed together with the documents referred to in that agreement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In addition to any other documents a party is obliged to file and serve under this rule, a party must file Parts 1, 2 and 3 of a Form F8 financial statement along with the party's applicable income documents, and must serve those Parts and applicable income documents under subrule (11), if one of the following is true:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the party is seeking to obtain a spousal support order;
the party is seeking to change, suspend or terminate a spousal support order;
a spousal support order is being sought against the party;
a spousal support order has been obtained against the party and another party is seeking to change, suspend or terminate that order.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Who must provide Part 3 of a Form F8 financial statement
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Each party who is making a claim under Part 5 of the Family Law Act or applying for a FHRMIRA order, or against whom such a claim or an application is being made, must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file Part 3 of a Form F8 financial statement, in addition to any other documents that the party is obliged to file under this rule, and
serve that Part 3 under subrule (11).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When party must file and serve documents
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party who is obliged to file documents under subrule (4), (5), (6), (7), (9) or (10) (in this subrule called the "disclosing party") must file all of those documents that have not already been filed, and serve on each of the other parties all of those documents that have not already been served on that party, as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the disclosing party's obligation arises because of a claim he or she made, he or she must file and serve those documents within 30 days, or such other period as the court may order, after service of the document in which the claim is made;

if the disclosing party's obligation arises because of a claim made by another party and the disclosing party resides in Canada or the United States of America, the disclosing party must file and serve those documents within 30 days, or such other period as the court may order, after service of the document in which the claim is made;

if the disclosing party's obligation arises because of a claim made by another party and the disclosing party resides in a country other than Canada or the United States of America, the disclosing party must file and serve those documents within 60 days, or such other period as the court may order, after service of the document in which the claim is made.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If Part 3 of a Form F8 financial statement is to be served on a party under this rule, the party serving the Part 3 must, if that party owns or has an interest in real property, serve, with the Part 3, the most recent assessment notice prepared for that real property by an assessment authority unless that assessment notice has already been served.

bcl:centertext.in:strong: Particulars of Form F8 Financial Statements

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a Form F8 financial statement lacks sufficient information, the other party may demand particulars.

If the party from whom particulars are demanded under subrule (13) fails to provide those particulars within 7 days after receipt of the demand, the court may, on terms it considers appropriate, make any order it considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Family Rules, including

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an order that particulars be served within a specified time, or
an order that a new Form F8 financial statement be served within a specified time.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If information contained in a document filed and served under this rule is rendered inaccurate or incomplete by a material change in circumstances, the party who filed and served that document must, promptly after that material change, serve on all parties

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a written statement setting out the accurate and complete information, or
a revised Form F8 financial statement containing the accurate and complete information.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the material change in circumstances referred to in subrule (15) is such that the party becomes obliged to file and serve documents under this rule that are additional to the documents previously filed and served under this rule by that party, the party must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serve copies of those additional documents within 28 days after the material change, and
comply with subrule (15) in relation to the previously served documents.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If written statement or particulars provided
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party provides particulars under subrule (13) or (14) (a) or serves a written statement under subrule (15) (a),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the particulars or statement may be treated at a trial or hearing as forming part of the original Form F8 financial statement of the party, and
the other party may, with leave of the court, require that the particulars or statement be

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: verified by an affidavit of the party providing the particulars or serving the statement, or
the subject of further cross-examination.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party who has served a Form F8 financial statement more than 91 days before the start of the trial or hearing of an application to which a Form F8 is relevant must serve on all parties an updated Form F8 financial statement at least 28 days before but not more than 63 days before the start of the trial or hearing.

If a party discloses business or corporate interests in a Form F8 financial statement served under this rule, the party receiving the Form F8 financial statement may, in writing, request the disclosing party to produce for inspection and copying specified documents or classes of documents in the disclosing party's possession or control that might reasonably be required to verify the valuation of the disclosing party's interest or to determine the disclosing party's income.
A party who receives a request under subrule (19) must, within 21 days after receipt, serve on the requesting party a notice stating

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a time and place, during normal business hours, at which the documents may be inspected, and
the cost of copying the documents.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Request to corporation, partnership or proprietorship
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a party who makes a request under subrule (19) is not satisfied with the reply to the request, the requesting party may serve on the corporation, partnership or proprietorship in which the disclosing party has disclosed an interest a written request to produce for inspection all documents that are relevant to the valuation of the interest or the determination of the disclosing party's income.
A corporation, partnership or proprietorship that receives a request under subrule (21) must, within 21 days after receipt, provide a written statement to the requesting party

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: detailing the documents in its possession or control that it is obliged to produce in response to the request,
identifying those documents, if any, in respect of which the corporation, partnership or proprietorship intends to seek an exemption under subrule (24),
specifying a time and place at which the documents for which an exemption is not being sought may be inspected, and
specifying the cost of copying the documents for which an exemption is not being sought.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A corporation, partnership or proprietorship or either of the parties may apply to the court at any time for directions respecting any request for production of documents under subrule (19) or (21), including directions respecting payment of the costs of copying the documents, and the court may give those directions accordingly.

A corporation, partnership or proprietorship may, within 21 days after the date a request is served on it under subrule (21), apply to the court for an order exempting it from the requirement to produce any document.
An application under subrule (23) or (24) may be made on behalf of a corporation or partnership by a person who has been authorized by the corporation or partnership for that purpose.
On an exemption application under subrule (24), the court may make an order exempting the applicant from the requirement to produce all or any of the requested documents if the court considers that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the documents and information already received by the party who made the request under subrule (21) are sufficient for the purposes of the main application,
the production of the documents is not necessary for the purposes of the main application,

in the case of a corporation, the prejudice that is likely to be suffered by the corporation, or to its directors or shareholders, if the exemption is not granted outweighs the prejudice that is likely to be suffered by the person requesting the documents if the exemption is granted, or

in the case of a partnership, the prejudice that is likely to be suffered by the partnership, or to its partners or associates, if the exemption is not granted outweighs the prejudice that is likely to be suffered by the person requesting the documents if the exemption is granted.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The court may order that the costs of producing documents under subrule (20) or (22) and the costs of an application under subrule (23) or (24) be paid in favour of or against

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: either of the parties to the family law case, or
the corporation, the partnership or the owner of the proprietorship, as the case may be.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Without limiting Rule 21-5 and any other powers the court may have under the Family Law Act, if a party fails to comply with a requirement under this rule to file or serve a Form F8 financial statement or any applicable income document or fails to comply with an order under this rule to provide particulars, the court may do any or all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: order that the Form F8 financial statement, applicable income document or particulars, as the case may be, be filed or served or both on terms the court considers appropriate;
dismiss all or part of that party's claim or application;
strike out all or part of that party's response to family claim or response to counterclaim;
proceed under Rule 21-7 to punish the party for contempt of court;
impose a fine under section 213 (2) (d) (iii) of the Family Law Act;
draw an adverse inference against the party;
attribute income to that party in an amount the court considers appropriate;
make an order as to costs.

bcl:text.in:em: [Rule 21-5 sets out what the court may do if parties fail to comply with these rules.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Any person who has access to documents obtained under this rule must keep the documents and any information contained in them in confidence and must not disclose the documents or information to anyone other than

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the purposes of a valuation of an asset,
for a determination of the disclosing party's income, or
in the course of permitting the documents to be introduced into evidence during the family law case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the court considers that public disclosure of any information filed under this rule would be a hardship on the person in respect of whom the information is filed,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the court may order that the whole or any part of the document in which the information is contained, and the whole or any part of the transcript of the cross-examination on the document, must promptly be sealed in an envelope, and
if an order is made under paragraph (a), no person may search the sealed documents without an order of the court.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If and to the extent that there is a conflict between any provision of this rule and a provision of the child support guidelines, the provision of the child support guidelines prevails.
For the purposes of subrule (31), it is not a conflict between the child support guidelines and this rule merely because this rule

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: requires a person to provide information that is different from or additional to the information, if any, that that person would be obliged to provide under the child support guidelines,

requires that certain information required by this rule but not by the child support guidelines be presented in a manner or form that is different from the manner or form in which information required under the child support guidelines is to be presented, or
requires the provision, in one manner or form, of information some or all of which is required under the child support guidelines to be provided in a different manner or form.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Required addresses for service of party represented by lawyer
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party to a family law case who is represented by a lawyer must have, as the party's addresses for service, both

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an e-mail address, if available, and
an accessible address that is an office address of that lawyer.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Required addresses for service of unrepresented party
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party to a family law case who is not represented by a lawyer must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: have, as the party's addresses for service, both

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an e-mail address, if available, and
an accessible address within 30 kilometres of the registry, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the party does not have an accessible address within 30 kilometres of the registry, have, as the party's addresses for service, both

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an e-mail address, if available, and
either

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a postal address in British Columbia, or

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may have, in addition to the address or addresses for service the party is required to have under subrule (1) or (1.1), one or more of the following as addresses for service:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a postal address;
a fax number;
an additional e-mail address.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party may change the party's address or addresses for service by filing and serving on the other parties a notice of address for service in Form F10 that shows, for the party,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the address or addresses for service required under subrule (1) or (1.1), and
any additional addresses for service referred to in subrule (2) that the party wishes to include.

bcl:lefttext.in:em: [See Rule 6-5 for rules on how service is effected outside British Columbia.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Documents normally to be served by ordinary service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to Rule 6-3 (1) and unless the court otherwise orders, documents to be served by a party under these Supreme Court Family Rules may be served by ordinary service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve documents by ordinary service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, ordinary service of a document is to be effected

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on a person, other than the FMEP Director, in any of the following ways:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving the document at the person's address for service;
by mailing the document by ordinary mail to the person's address for service;
subject to subrule (5) of this rule, if a fax number is provided as one of the person's addresses for service, by faxing the document to that fax number together with a fax cover sheet;
if an e-mail address is provided as one of the person's addresses for service, by e-mailing the document to that e-mail address, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the FMEP Director by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: mailing it to the post office box number provided by the FMEP Director, or
faxing it to the fax number provided by the FMEP Director.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When service by delivery is deemed to be completed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document served by leaving it at a person's address for service is deemed to be served on the person as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is left at the address for service at or before 4 p.m. on a day that is not a Saturday or holiday, the document is deemed to be served on the day of service;
if the document is left at the address for service on a Saturday or holiday or after 4 p.m. on any other day, the document is deemed to be served on the next day that is not a Saturday or holiday.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When service by mail is deemed to be completed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document sent for service by ordinary mail under this rule is deemed to be served one week later on the same day of the week as the day of mailing or, if that deemed day of service is a Saturday or holiday, on the next day that is not a Saturday or holiday.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When documents may be served by fax
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document may be served by fax as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document, including the fax cover sheet, is less than 30 pages, the document may be served by fax at any time;
if the document, including the fax cover sheet, is 30 pages or more, the document may be served by fax if it is transmitted

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: between 5 p.m. and the following 8 a.m., or
at another time if the person receiving the document agreed to that time before service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When service by fax or e-mail is deemed to be completed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document transmitted for service by fax or e-mail under this rule is deemed to be served as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is transmitted before 4 p.m. on a day that is not a Saturday or holiday, the document is deemed to be served on the day of transmission;
if the document is transmitted on a Saturday or holiday or after 4 p.m. on any other day, the document is deemed to be served on the next day that is not a Saturday or holiday.

bcl:lefttext.in:em: [Sunday is a holiday for the purposes of this Rule.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If no address for service given
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If, despite these Supreme Court Family Rules, a party on whom a document is to be served has no address for service, and if these Supreme Court Family Rules do not specify that the document must be served by personal service on the party,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the document may be served by mailing a copy of the document by ordinary mail to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the lawyer acting for the party in the family law case, or
if the party has no lawyer in the family law case, to the party's last known address, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: subrule (4) applies.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Request for copy of document served by e-mail
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document is transmitted for service by e-mail and the person receiving the document requests, within 3 days of receiving that document, that a copy be sent to another address for service for that person, the party who served the document by e-mail must provide the copy at the requested address for service within 7 days of receiving that request or as agreed upon by the parties.

bcl:lefttext.in:em: [See Rule 6-5 for rules on how service is effected outside British Columbia.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When documents must be served by personal service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, the following documents must be served by personal service in accordance with subrule (2):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a notice of family claim;
a petition;
a counterclaim if that counterclaim is being served on a person who has not yet filed a pleading in the family law case;
a notice of withdrawal under Rule 2-2 (3) or 4-5 (3);
a notice of application to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: change, suspend or terminate an existing final order,
set aside or replace the whole or any part of an agreement filed under Rule 2-1 (2),
change or set aside the determination of a parenting coordinator filed under Rule 2-1.1 (1), or
change, suspend or terminate an arbitration award filed under Rule 2-1.2 (1),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: and the accompanying documents referred to in Rule 10-6 (6);
a summons to appear at a default hearing or show cause hearing under Rule 15-5 (1);
a summons to appear at a committal hearing under Rule 15-5 (2);
a notice of application under Rule 21-7 for an order for contempt;
a subpoena to a witness who is not a party;
a subpoena to a debtor;
Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 133/2012, s. 8 (b).]

any document not mentioned in paragraphs (a) to (k) of this subrule that is to be served on a person who is not a party to the family law case or who has not provided an address for service in the family law case under Rule 10-6 (10).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to serve documents by personal service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, personal service of a document is to be effected,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is to be served on an individual, by having a person who is not a party and who is at least 19 years of age leave the document with the individual to be served,
if the document is to be served on the FMEP Director, by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: mailing it to the post office box number provided by the FMEP Director, or
faxing it to the fax number provided by the FMEP Director,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is to be served on a corporation,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by leaving a copy of the document with the president, chair, mayor or other chief officer of the corporation,
by leaving a copy of the document with the city clerk or municipal clerk,

by leaving a copy of the document with the manager, cashier, superintendent, treasurer, secretary, clerk or agent of the corporation or of any branch or agency of the corporation in British Columbia, or
in the manner provided by the Business Corporations Act or any enactment relating to the service of court documents,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: and, for the purpose of this paragraph, if the chief place of business of the corporation is outside British Columbia, every person who, within British Columbia, transacts or carries on any of the business of, or any business for, that corporation is deemed to be an agent of the corporation,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is to be served on an unincorporated association, other than a trade union, by leaving a copy of the document with any officer of the association,
if the document is to be served on a trade union, by leaving a copy of the document with any officer of the trade union or with a business agent,
if the document is to be served on an infant, in the manner provided by the Infants Act,
if the document is to be served on a mentally incompetent person, by leaving a copy of the document

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: with the person's committee or, if there is no committee, with the person with whom the mentally incompetent person resides or in whose care he or she is or with the person appointed by the court to be served in the mentally incompetent person's place, and
with the Public Guardian and Trustee,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: and in no case is it necessary to show the original document,
if the document is to be served on a principal referred to in subrule (3), in accordance with subrules (3) to (5), or
if the document is to be served on the Attorney General, in accordance with subrule (6).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document to be served on the Attorney General must be served at the Ministry of Attorney General in the City of Victoria, and is sufficiently served if it is left during office hours with any lawyer on the staff of the Attorney General at Victoria or mailed by registered mail to the Deputy Attorney General at Victoria.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: When personal service is deemed to be completed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A document served by personal service is deemed to be served as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: if the document is served before 4 p.m. on a day that is not a Saturday or holiday, the document is deemed to be served on the day of service;
if the document is served on a Saturday or holiday or after 4 p.m. on any other day, the document is deemed to be served on the next day that is not a Saturday or holiday.

bcl:lefttext.in:em: [Sunday is a holiday for the purposes of this subrule.]

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a notice of family claim, counterclaim or petition has not been served on a person, but the person files a response to family claim, response to counterclaim or response to petition or attends at the trial or hearing, the notice of family claim, counterclaim or petition is deemed to have been served on that person on the date the person files or attends.
If it is impracticable to serve a document by personal service or if the person to be served by personal service

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cannot be found after a diligent search, or
is evading service of the documents,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the court may, on application without notice, make an order for substituted service granting permission to use an alternative method of service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If an alternative service method is permitted
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document is to be served by an alternative method permitted under subrule (1), a copy of the entered substituted service order that granted permission to use that alternative method must be served with the document unless

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the court otherwise orders, or
the alternative method of service permitted under subrule (1) is service by advertisement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If, under subrule (1), the court permits a document to be served by advertisement, the advertisement must be in Form F11.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service outside British Columbia without leave
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A notice of family claim, counterclaim, petition or other document in a family law case may be served on a person outside British Columbia without leave if the court has jurisdiction in relation to the family law case under section 10 of the Court Jurisdiction and Proceedings Transfer Act, section 74 of the Family Law Act or section 3 or 4 of the Divorce Act.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application for leave to serve outside the jurisdiction
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: In any case not provided for in subrule (1), leave of the court must be obtained before a notice of family claim, counterclaim, petition or other document may be served outside British Columbia, and the court may grant such leave on an application referred to in subrule (3).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Applications may be made without notice
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An application for leave to serve a person outside British Columbia

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may be made without notice in accordance with Rule 10-5 (1) (c), and
must be supported by an affidavit or other evidence showing

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: in what place or country that person is or probably may be found, and
the grounds on which the application is made.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service of order and related documents
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If an order is made granting leave to serve a notice of family claim, counterclaim, petition or other document outside British Columbia, the following documents must be served with that notice of family claim, counterclaim, petition or other document:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the filed notice of application, or requisition, for leave to serve;
a copy of all filed affidavits in support of the application;
a copy of the entered order granting leave to serve.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: This rule does not invalidate service of a document outside British Columbia without leave of the court if the document could have been validly served apart from this rule.
Despite this rule, the parties to a contract may agree

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that the court will have jurisdiction to hear a family law case in respect of the contract, and
that a document in the family law case may be served

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at any place, within or outside British Columbia,
on any party,
on any person on behalf of any party, or
in any manner

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: specified in the contract.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Contract does not invalidate effective service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Service of a document in accordance with a contract referred to in subrule (6) is effective service, but no contractual stipulation as to service of a document invalidates service that would otherwise be effective under these Supreme Court Family Rules.
In subrules (9) to (12), Convention means the Convention on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters, signed at the Hague on November 15, 1965.
A document may be served outside British Columbia

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a manner provided by these Supreme Court Family Rules for service in British Columbia,
in a manner provided by the law of the place where service is made if, by that manner of service, the document could reasonably be expected to come to the notice of the person to be served, or
in a state that is a contracting state under the Convention, in a manner provided by or permitted under the Convention.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Service of a document outside British Columbia may be proved

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in a manner provided by these Supreme Court Family Rules for proof of service in British Columbia,
in the manner provided for proof of service by the law of the place where service was made regardless of the manner under subrule (9) by which service was effected, or
in accordance with the Convention, if service was effected under subrule (9) (c).

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If service is to be made in accordance with Article 5 of the Convention, Forms F12 and F13 must be used.
If an authority has, in accordance with Article 6 of the Convention, completed a certificate in Form F14, the certificate is evidence of the facts stated in it.
Service of a document is proved as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: service of a notice of family claim on a person is proved

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by filing an affidavit of personal service in Form F15, or
by the person filing a response to family claim;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: service of a counterclaim on a person who has not filed a pleading is proved

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by filing an affidavit of personal service in Form F15, or
by the person filing a response to counterclaim;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: service of a petition on a person is proved

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by filing an affidavit of personal service in Form F15, or
by the person filing a response to petition;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: service of any other document served by personal service is proved by filing an affidavit of personal service in Form F15;
service of any document that is served by ordinary service is proved

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by filing an affidavit of ordinary service in Form F16, or
by filing a requisition in Form F17 to which is attached a written acknowledgment of receipt signed by the party or lawyer on whom the document was served.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Service of a document by a sheriff may be proved by a certificate in Form F18 endorsed on a copy of the document.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Service on member of Canadian Armed Forces
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a member of the Canadian Armed Forces has been served with a document by an officer of the Canadian Armed Forces, proof of the service in the form of a certificate annexed to a copy of the document served, signed by the officer and stating his or her rank and when, where and how service was effected, may be filed as proof of service.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Admissibility of other evidence of service
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Nothing in subrule (1) or (2) restricts the court from considering any other evidence of service that the court considers appropriate in the circumstances.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: If service is alleged to be ineffective
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If a document has been served in accordance with this Part but a person can show that the document

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: did not come to his or her notice,
came to his or her notice later than when it was served, or
was incomplete or illegible,

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: the court may set aside an order, extend time, order an adjournment or make such other order as it considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Family Rules.
A party may request a judicial case conference at any time, whether or not one or more judicial case conferences have already been held in the family law case.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Requirement to hold judicial case conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Subject to subrules (3) and (4), unless a judicial case conference has been conducted in a family law case, a party to the family law case must not serve on another party a notice of application or an affidavit in support.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Applications that may be brought before a judicial case conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party to a family law case may file and serve a notice of application and supporting affidavits in respect of any of the following applications even though a judicial case conference has not been conducted in the family law case:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 133/2012, s. 10 (a).]
an application for an order under section 91 of the Family Law Act restraining the disposition of any property at issue;

an application for an order under section 32 or 39 of the Family Homes on Reserves and Matrimonial Interests or Rights Act (Canada) or a First Nation's law made under that Act with respect to an equivalent matter;
an application for a consent order;
an application without notice;
an application to change, suspend or terminate a final order;
an application to set aside or replace the whole or any part of an agreement;
an application to change or set aside the determination of a parenting coordinator.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Court may relieve party from requirement of subrule (2)
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: On application by a party, the court may relieve a party from the requirement of subrule (2) if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: it is premature to require the parties to attend a judicial case conference,
it is impracticable or unfair to require the party to comply with the requirements of subrule (2),
the application referred to in subrule (2) is urgent,
delaying the application referred to in subrule (2) or requiring the party to attend a judicial case conference is or might be dangerous to the health or safety of any person, or
the court considers it appropriate that the party be relieved from that requirement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To bring an application for relief under subrule (4), a party must file a requisition in Form F18.1.
On an application for relief under subrule (4), the court may do one or more of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: require that further material be provided;
require that the party or lawyer appear in person to speak to the application;
make the order without requiring the party or lawyer to appear to speak to the application;
refuse to make the order;
make any order the court considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Family Rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: How to request a judicial case conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: To request a judicial case conference, a party must file a notice of judicial case conference in Form F19.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What must be served if judicial case conference is requested
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The party requesting a judicial case conference must serve on all parties, at least 30 days before the date set for the judicial case conference,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of the filed notice of judicial case conference, and
a copy of the Form F8 financial statement, if any, required under Rule 5-1, along with the applicable income documents referred to in section B of Part 1 of the Form F8 financial statement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Court may require a judicial case conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At any stage of a family law case, the court may direct that a judicial case conference take place and may order a party to

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: file a notice of judicial case conference, and
serve a copy of the filed notice of judicial case conference along with any financial documents required under subrule (8) (b) in accordance with subrule (8).

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Form F8 financial statement must be filed before judicial case conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A party serving a notice of judicial case conference in accordance with subrule (8) or (9) must, at least 7 days before the date set for the judicial case conference, file the original of the Form F8 financial statement, if any, required under Rule 5-1 along with the applicable income documents referred to in section B of Part 1 of the Form F8 financial statement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Other parties must file and serve Form F8 financial statement
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At least 7 days before the date set for a judicial case conference, a party who has been served with a notice of judicial case conference in accordance with subrule (8) or (9) must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: serve on the party who served the notice of judicial case conference and on every other party a copy of the Form F8 financial statement, if any, required under Rule 5-1 along with the applicable income documents referred to in section B of Part 1 of the Form F8 financial statement, and
file the original Form F8 financial statement along with the applicable income documents referred to in section B of Part 1 of the Form F8 financial statement.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judicial case conference must be conducted by judge or associate judge
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judicial case conference must be conducted by a judge or associate judge.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Who must attend the judicial case conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Unless the court otherwise orders, if a judicial case conference is held, each of the parties and the party's lawyer must attend that judicial case conference.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Application must be made by requisition
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: An application under subrule (13) for an order exempting a person from attending a judicial case conference must be made by requisition in Form F19.1.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Absent parties must be available and accessible by telephone or other means
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: If the court orders that a party need not attend a judicial case conference, the party must be readily available and immediately accessible for consultation during the judicial case conference, either in person or by telephone.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: What happens at the judicial case conference
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: The court may do one or more of the following at a judicial case conference:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: identify the issues that are in dispute and those that are not in dispute and explore ways in which the issues in dispute may be resolved without recourse to trial;
make orders to which all the parties consent;
mediate any of the issues in dispute;
with the consent of the parties, refer the parties to a family dispute resolution professional, within the meaning of the Family Law Act, other than a family justice counsellor;

refer the parties to a family justice counsellor, or to a person designated by the Attorney General to provide specialized support assistance, if the court has received written advice from the regional manager that the family justice counsellor or designated person is readily available to the parties;
direct a party to attend the Parenting after Separation program operated by the Family Justice Services Division (Justice Services Branch), Ministry of Attorney General;
make orders respecting amendment of a pleading, petition or response to petition within a fixed time;
make orders requiring that particulars be provided in relation to any matter raised in a pleading;
make orders respecting discovery of documents;
make orders respecting examinations for discovery;
direct that any or all applications must be made within a specified time;
reserve a trial date for the family law case or reserve a date for a trial that is restricted to issues defined by the parties;
set a date for a trial management conference under Rule 14-3;
make any orders that may be made at a trial management conference under Rule 14-3 (9);
without hearing witnesses, give a non-binding opinion on the probable outcome of a hearing or trial;
without limiting any other orders respecting timing that may be made under this subrule, make orders respecting timing of events;
adjourn the judicial case conference;
direct the parties to attend a further judicial case conference at a specified date and time;
make any procedural order or give any direction that the court considers will further the object of these Supreme Court Family Rules.

bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Without limiting any other power of the court under these Supreme Court Family Rules, if a party fails to appear at a judicial case conference, the court may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: proceed in the absence of the party who failed to appear,
exercise any of the powers of the court under subrule (15) of this rule, and
order that the party who failed to appear pay costs to the other party.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Judge or associate judge may be seized of further applications
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At a judicial case conference, or at any other time, a judge or associate judge may order that all applications in the family law case be heard by that judge or associate judge.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Other judges or associate judges may hear applications
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: A judge or associate judge who has made an order under subrule (17) may at any time direct that any or all applications in the family law case may be heard by another judge or associate judge.
Proceedings at a judicial case conference must be recorded, but no part of that recording may be made available to or used by any person without court order.

If, at any stage of a family law case, the parties jointly request a settlement conference by filing a requisition in Form F17 or a judge or associate judge directs the parties to attend a settlement conference, the parties must attend before a judge or associate judge who must, in private and without hearing witnesses, explore all possibilities of settlement of the issues that are outstanding.
Proceedings at a settlement conference must be recorded, but no part of that recording may be made available to or used by any person without court order.
A judge who has presided at a settlement conference must not preside at the trial, unless all parties consent.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Case planning conference may be requested
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: At any time after a judicial case conference has been held in a family law case, a party may request a case planning conference by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: obtaining a date and time for the case planning conference from the registry, and
filing a notice of case planning conference in Form F19.2.

bcl:subrule.bcl:marginalnote: Case planning conference may be directed
bcl:subrule.bcl:text: Without limiting subrule (1), at any time after a judicial case conference has been held in a family law case, the court

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: may direct that a case planning conference take place, and
in that case, must direct that a party request a case planning conference in accordance with subrule (1).
